instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2132: What is 820-2132? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-2140: What is 820-2140? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU_REG: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU_REG? PPVCORE_S0_CPU_REG is a single phase of CPU VCORE before it is combined into PPVCORE_S0_CPU .
definitions.5VS0_EN: What is 5VS0_EN? 5VS0_ EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Folks, I just joined the group. Just a hobbyist. Bought a non-working 2007 17" Macbook Pro. Very nice and not working :) Will attempt to repair.
I had green light. Took out the motherboard and no green light now. a few questions if you could please answer.
1- Does the Magsafe charger has a right way to plug in? Its not keyed so can be plugged in any which way!
2- What are the voltage levels on the Charger?
3- This board A1229  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2132</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is supposed to have 18.5v in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. I measure 16.5v. Does this mean the Magsafe is inadequate? If so can I test with 18.5 Power Injection?
4- Have purchased a boardview file for this from appleschematics.com. I also have a PDF with matching numbers. There are transistors in both which are not present on the board. There is not even a place for it. It was not taken out. Just wondering if I have the right boardview file. How do I know I have the correct boardview file and where do I get just the one I need? Don't want to buy the whole pack just yet.
5- Louis does not have tutoring anymore. Is there any place which does?

Thanks in advance for your attention.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Be aware that this will have a dead GPU in any case. Also it's easy to have bad contact in the Magsafe port with old machines, and in the FFC connector between LIO board and logic board.
1/ Magsafe can be plugged in both ways. If you don't have at least some experience with these machines I'd not recommend trying to jump straight into board repair.
2/ It depends on the Magsafe. This board requires a Magsafe1 85W which can send out 18.5V but it can also decrease the voltage a little bit when idling, and it'll only send out 6V when not connected to the machine.
3/ <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> should be somewhere around 12.6V as usual.
4/ No sure why you'd pay for schematics/boardviews when they're available for free.
Like every logic boards, some components will not be populated because they're not necessary on production boards. They're annotated with NO STUFF or a BOM option that's not listed for production in the BOM option table.
5/ I'd recommend watching Louis Rossmann videos as most of the information is readily available in them. There's also his repair guide and his wiki as well as other sources of information such as [URL]https://logi.wiki/[/URL] , badcaps.net and this forum.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

You can try to solve the power problem for this machine, but as already mentioned, this board could have bad GPU; so be aware of that.

"is supposed to have 18.5v in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. I measure 16.5v"
Only possible if <TRANSISTOR>Q7901</TRANSISTOR> is shorted.
Change it and also check R/<CAPACITOR>C7903</CAPACITOR> and <DIODE>D7900</DIODE>; may need to change <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> too.

About Magsafe light, which is the code of your LIO board?
Many times LM397 gets burnt there, but could be other thing.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Thanks for your response.
Here is what I have:
Power Board
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2140</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A

<TRANSISTOR>Q7901</TRANSISTOR>:
PIN VOLTAGE
5       16.26
1,2,3 12.69
4       13.43 

<DIODE>D7900</DIODE>:
1         5.08
2       17.38

I have all pics attached.
I have done more testing and tracing. Kind of fun until I get to the end and hit a block:

Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_REG</SIGNAL> which points to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
VDD is missing in <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
Which depends on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPU_IMVP</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPU_IMVP</SIGNAL> depends on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5_S0_FET</SIGNAL> depends on PP5V_S0P5VS0FET and <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>
Got 5 volts on the first and 0 on <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> comes from ICHM8M <CHIP>U2300</CHIP>

I have all pics attached.
What is this chip?
How do I go forward from here?

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2300</CHIP> is the Intel sothbridge chip.

Please post accurate and actual measurments.
You've said to have 16.5V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; which is same at L7900 and pins 1-3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7900</TRANSISTOR>.
12.6V is good voltage there; do not waste time around <CHIP>U7900</CHIP>, if you get this voltage.

How do you get <SIGNAL>5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL>, with 0V at <SIGNAL>5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>???
Is <TRANSISTOR>Q7020</TRANSISTOR> shorted I/O?

"VDD is missing in <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>"
Check diode mode to ground there.
Is <RESISTOR>R7112</RESISTOR> burnt?
Do you get PVCC?

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Sorry for inaccuracy.

I have measured again and very accurately and its been fun.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.65v checked at L7900

Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_REG</SIGNAL>, and no screen, no chime...

On <TRANSISTOR>Q7100</TRANSISTOR> pin 5 I have 12.65 ( <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> )

On <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> pins 34 and 35 are Zero and both sides of <RESISTOR>R7112</RESISTOR> are Zero and <RESISTOR>R7112</RESISTOR> is 10 Ohms

On <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> VDD is missing. Ohmmeter test to ground is 16.89Kh ( red probe on ground). Pin 22 is Zero, VDD depends on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPU_IMVP</SIGNAL> and this depends on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> Comes from <TRANSISTOR>Q7020</TRANSISTOR>

On <TRANSISTOR>Q7020</TRANSISTOR>, there is 4.97v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_P5VS0FET</SIGNAL> at pin7, [B]3.38v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> at pins1,5,8,[/B] I have 4.94v on pin4

The question is why we have 3.38v instead of 5v!

Checking around <TRANSISTOR>Q7020</TRANSISTOR> I see <TRANSISTOR>Q7002</TRANSISTOR>

On <TRANSISTOR>Q7002</TRANSISTOR> ( confusing data between boardview and Schematics on which pin is which )

pin 6 is 4.96v ( used for other circuit )

pin 3 is 4.96v

pin 5 is zero

All other pins are zero



Pin 5 which is Gate comes from <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> which comes from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> comes from ICH8M/<CHIP>U2300</CHIP>


 Where to go from here?

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
So you are searching for CPU vcore before geting the voltages from pages 62-64?
You can't get S0 voltage before S3.

Do you say <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is not prresent?
What about <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?

Take a look at Power On Sequence List from page 3.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Thanks for the hints. I followed your suggestions as per below.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.65V

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16V

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 4.97V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 25mV

Moving to <TRANSISTOR>Q7000</TRANSISTOR> to find <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>

Pin 4 has 4.97v

Pin 3 has 4.94v

Moving to <TRANSISTOR>Q7012</TRANSISTOR> to see if it opens to ground

Pin 6 has 4.96v

Pin 2 has ZERO which comes in from <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL>

This leads to <SIGNAL>PM_S4_STATE_L</SIGNAL> which comes from ICH8M/<CHIP>U2300</CHIP>



Where to go from here?

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
You didn't really post exact level for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> signals.
Check for pulse at least; triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground (temporary contact only).

Southbridge requires some other signals (reset, RTC?), to start power on sequence.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
I am not quite sure what I should check. Where to check for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/3?
Where do I check for those 2? At ICH8M? That has lots of pins and not exposed. So not sure how to check that.
I followed the diagram and went forward from G3H and S5 and did not run into those 2 above to test.
To answer <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4v. Checked that on J9600 pin 5.
If you could please state what I should check next. Appreciate.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL>.
Use boardview, you will find points where to test them.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
On baordview I can find <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> on <TRANSISTOR>Q7051</TRANSISTOR> and its zero at the moment. cannot find <SIGNAL>S4_L</SIGNAL>
Forgive me but how do I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>? And what will that tell me?

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Use <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> pads, instead of power button.
When pressing power button, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> both must pulse, at least.
If not, check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> must be steady high.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
I am guessing you mean to short the pads which does the same as power button.
Shorted the pads together, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> was dead zero.
Could not find a test point for <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> accessible. Under <CHIP>U4900</CHIP> pin 45 and no test point.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is steady 3.39

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
"short the pads which does the same as power button"
Only temporar contact, like prressing power button.
Do not keep the pads shorted.

Check RTC signals of <CHIP>U2300</CHIP>.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
I did it as you mentioned.
 <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> was dead zero
I checked across <RESISTOR>R2811</RESISTOR> for the RTC
<SIGNAL>SB_RTC_X1</SIGNAL> 300mV
<SIGNAL>SB_RTC_X2</SIGNAL> 227mV

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message: Also <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is a tiny bit warm after being on the charger for couple of hours

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Reading your posts, I was thinking you want to learn.
We have lot of information on the forum.
We discussed many-many times about what we understand as RTC signals.
I didn't mention RTC clock, what you've checked.

Please, post <SIGNAL>SB_RTC_RST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SB_SM_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SB_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SB_LAN100_SLP</SIGNAL>.
As you can see in page 23, all go to southbridge RTC block.

Be aware, this old board can already have a dead GPU.
It may worth the time only for training.

The forum goal is to help the members in a repair process.
If you are interested in training, contact Rossmann staff.
This may depend on your location.
I can tell you that reading the forum you can learn a lot of things.
Apart of solutions, we have theory posted too.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Would love to get training. They state no more training on their site. I am on the West Coast far away from NY. Will call them and try.
I will look at other parts of the Forum. The videos from Louis do not discuss what you are asking here. They discuss mostly the power rails. If this problem were just power rails I would have gotten it by now. Would be nice to see what the problem is here.
Here are the measurements you asked:
<SIGNAL>SB_RTC_RST_L</SIGNAL> 3.29V
<SIGNAL>SB_SM_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> 3.0V
<SIGNAL>SB_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.2V
<SIGNAL>SB_LAN100_SLP</SIGNAL> 3.2V

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Do you get steady voltage at L7320/60?

Do you have schematic/boardview for LIO board?
Still missing Magsafe light?

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
4.97v across L7320
While I was moving the board around the charger light came on.
reseated the power cables and the green charge light came on.
That is my inexperience.
Will go through all the rails over again.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Got green charger light by moving reseating cables. Testing from square 1.
L7320 has consistent voltage across.

Going down the power rails

PP5VS3 missing

<SIGNAL>PM_S4_STATE_L</SIGNAL> missing on <TRANSISTOR>Q7002</TRANSISTOR>

Which goes back to <CHIP>U2300</CHIP> Chip

It all winds up at <CHIP>U2300</CHIP>

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
You can touch <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> ball under <CHIP>U4900</CHIP>; use fine tip multimeter probes.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.aliexpress.com/wholesale?catId=0&initiative_id=SB_20210224093000&SearchText=fine+tip+multimeter+lead[/URL]
If you catch drop pulse there, when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, the the problem is on <CHIP>U2300</CHIP> side.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message: That is pin 45 on <CHIP>U4900</CHIP>. I cannot find any test points for that.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
That ball is just on the border.
A fine tip can reach it...

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message: I could reach pins on the border. The 3rd one in I believe its pin 45 and has constant 3.3V. Attached the keyboard and pressed the power button and no change to the voltage. The other 2 , i.e. pins 15 and 30 were Zero.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Attached keyboard why?
I already explained you how to simulate power button.
Power button can be bad.
If you use <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> pads, is better.
Just check first if <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> drops to 0V.
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> should react at same time.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
This was tough one. I have 3.4v at <RESISTOR>R5070</RESISTOR>
I don't get any pulse <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> when I short the pads.
It remains at 3.4V.
No voltage at pin 45 on <CHIP>U2300</CHIP>. Its tough to measure this one. I was wrong previously.

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> pad 1 is placed on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
Pad 2 is ground.
How can't drop <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, if you tie it to ground???

threads.title: A1229 Voltages and Magsafe
threads.message:
Thanks for you support.
I hit a snag. Have to figure out what went wrong.
Had some smoke and I think I fried <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.
Will get that part from Louis and will replace.
